content.rendered:
New for 2025: New entry for 1982; audio for 2008; video for 2023

1973: Bruce opens for Jerry Lee Lewis and Chuck Berry at the University of Maryland. After his set, Bruce and the E Street Band (plus Southside Johnny) serve as the backing band at no charge for Lewis and Berry, remaining on stage the entire night. The band has no rehearsal time with Berry, who keeps the band on their toes the entire night. Watch Bruce tell the story below. (Thanks to Dave Homorody for the photo!)

1974: Bruce and the E Street Band play an intimate (less than 300 attendees) outdoor show at Swarthmore College.

1976: Bruce plays the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville.

1981: Flo and Eddie guest-star on “Hungry Heart” when the River Tour arrives in Rotterdam.

1982: At the Power Station in New York City, Bruce works on several songs for what would eventually become Born in the U.S.A.

1988: Bruce wraps up a five-night stand at the L.A. Sports Arena. This show is available as part of Bruce’s official archive series–get it here.

1997: Greatest Hits is certified 3x multi-platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America.

1999: At the Reunion show in Lyon, France, Jon Bon Jovi guest-stars on “Hungry Heart.”

2003: Bruce rehearses at the Count Basie Theater for Bobby Bandiera’s Hope Concert benefit the following day.

2005: On the second night of his solo acoustic tour, in Grand Prairie, Texas, Bruce plays “Two Faces” for the first time in 17 years, and Jimmy LaFave guest-stars on “Oklahoma Hills.” Also new to the set list tonight: “Galveston Bay” and “My Hometown.”

2008: Greensboro gets a fantastic Magic show, as Bruce opens with the tour premieres of “Roulette” and “Don’t Look Back,” before segueing to “Radio Nowhere,” “Out in the Street,” and “The Promised Land.” Opening packs don’t get much better than that. Also tour premiering tonight: “Mary’s Place.” This show is available as part of Bruce’s official archive series–get it here.

2009: Philadelphia always seems to get great shows, and the Working on a Dream Tour keeps up the tradition. Night One at the Spectrum features the tour premieres of “The Fever,” “Mountain of Love,” “Fire” and “You Can’t Sit Down.” For more highlights from this show, see my Where the Band Was report from this date.

2013: Bruce and the E Street Band rehearse for the next leg of the Wrecking Ball Tour at Nordisk Film Studios in Oslo.

2017: Tom Hanks interviews Bruce at the Tribeca Film Festival.

2021: From My Home to Yours continues with Episode 21, “Waiting on a Friend” on E Street Radio.

2023: Bruce and the E Street Band kick off the European leg of their 2023 World Tour in Barcelona with some special guests: former U.S. First Lady Michelle Obama and actress Kate Capshaw join Patti Scialfa on stage for backing vocals on “Glory Days.” The run of nightly tour premieres continue with “Human Touch.”

excerpt.rendered: On this date: Bruce is interviewed by Tom Hanks, Jon Bon Jovi makes a guest appearance, and the E Street Band backs Chuck Berry. More highlights inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: September 2
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The Human Rights Now! Tour kicks off, Bruce and Bob Seger meet for the first time, Bruce and the E Street Band help inaugurate the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and more.

jetpack-related-posts.title: MatR: Bruce Springsteen and Jerry Lee Lewis: Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin’ On
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Twice in the mid-nineties, Bruce and Jerry Lee Lewis tackled Lewis' first great hit together, and both times they fell short. Let's take a look and listen to find out why.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: May 20
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Watch Bruce and his new band rehearse for their 1992 tour, and then listen to Joe Ely and Jerry Lee Lewis join them on stage a year later. These and more highlights from this date inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: MatR: Bruce Springsteen, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Joe Ely: Great Balls of Fire
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Bruce took two cracks at performing Jerry Lee Lewis' signature song with The Killer, but it took a guest appearance by the Jerry Lee-influenced Joe Ely to get it right.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: November 5
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Big day: Bruce releases his second studio album, films a 1980 River show for posterity (and an eventual box set), and makes guest appearances with Huey Lewis, Bob Geldof, and Eric Church. Lots more inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: October 12
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Bruce is officially a Broadway star when his show opens at long last. Plus: Bruce plays in Brazil for the first time and is inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. More highlights inside.
